subject: Re: American pronunciation
msgSnippet: Chuck, There is a click & listen sound library for the 40 sounds of American English in a letter matrix that includes IPA and Shavian. This is quite old and
messageBody:
Chuck,

There is a "click & listen" sound library for the 40 sounds of
American English in a letter matrix that includes IPA and Shavian.

This is quite old and in need of an update but see if it fits your
needs. One change would be more than one short O pronunciation and a
non-rhotic pronunciation of /3/ and /@/: surfer = s3`f@` and s3f@.
{can surfer and suffer be distinguished in a non-rhotic
pronunciation?)

http://victorian.fortunecity.com/vangogh/555/Spell/saunds-eng2.html

--Steve

--- Chuck Peck <chuck091956@o...> wrote:

> I think we go through this conversation about every 3-6 months. One
thing is not everything to all. QS is a phonic character set based
on British English. ... the character's sound would be an oral
pronunciation of each character.

A audio tape or CD could definitely set a standard sound byte for each
character. Then we could all use it as proposed, as a phonic
representation of our oral conversation. Any attempt to change the
sound byte for each character to fit different dialects would be
counter to QS's original purpose.

One character needs to only represent one sound. Which character we
use to express our words all depends on our accuracy in hearing and
analyzing our own words in relationship to the sound bytes associated
with the QS characters.

I propose we build an audio library as a reference to the sound of
each QS character. In staying with the heart of Reed's original
intent, I think this audio library should be done in British English.
Then everyone can use a repeatable set of sounds/characters to
represent their communications.

> Chuck Peck
> cak pek < Jerome font

Chuck,

There is a "click & listen" sound library for the 40 sounds of 
American English in a letter matrix that includes IPA and Shavian.

This is quite old and in need of an update but see if it fits your 
needs.  One change would be more than one short O pronunciation and a 
non-rhotic pronunciation of /3/ and /@/:  surfer = s3`f@` and s3f@.
{can surfer and suffer be distinguished in a non-rhotic 
pronunciation?)

http://victorian.fortunecity.com/vangogh/555/Spell/saunds-eng2.html 

--Steve

thing is not everything to all.  QS is a phonic character set based

A audio tape or CD could definitely set a standard sound byte for each
character. Then we could all use it as proposed, as a phonic 
representation of our oral conversation. Any attempt to change the 
sound byte for each character to fit different dialects would be 
counter to QS's original purpose.
  
One character needs to only represent one sound. Which character we 
use to express our words all depends on our accuracy in hearing and 
analyzing our own words in relationship to the sound bytes associated 
with the QS characters.
 
I propose we build an audio library as a reference to the sound of 
each QS character. In staying with the heart of Reed's original 
intent, I think this audio library should be done in British English. 
Then everyone can use a repeatable set of sounds/characters to 
represent their communications.
 
> Chuck Peck
